div.p:
XXXI 358
Mead The reason why these extensive
treesp plains are covered
with grasses only and
the little islands with
but scraggy trees may
be accounted for by
the fact observable every-
where in this country
that where water stands
for any length of time
in this country trees
cannot live - The
want of speedy drainage
destroys them and injures
it influences the growth
25 of those that are planted
on the islands for they
have no depth of earth
except not subjected to
the souring influence
of the stagnant water
The plains of Lobale
to the West of these are
said to be much more
extensive than any we
saw, and their vegetation
possesses similar peculiarities
When the stagnant
rain water had all soaked
in as must happen
during the months in
which there is no rain
travellers are put to shiftsstraits
for want of water - This
359
which is given on native
testimony for ^ but I can very
well believe that level
plains in which neither
wells nor gullies are
met with may after
the dry season present the
opposite extreme to what we
witnessed - Water could
however always be got by
digging; as a proof of
which we had on our
return when brought to
a stand on this very
plain by ^ severe fever; about fifteen
twelve miles from the Leeba
my men dug down a
few feet and found
26 an abundant supply
And we saw on one of the
islands the garden of a
man who in the dry season
had drankdrunk water from
a well in like manner
Plains like these cannot
be inhabited while the
present system of cultivation
lasts - The population at
present is not so very large
as to need them - They find
garden ground enough won
the gentle slopes at nethe
sides of the rivulets and
possess no cattle to eat off
the millions of acres of
360
fine hay we were now
wading through Any one
who has visited the Cape
Colony will understand me
when I say these immense
crops of grass have very
little resemble sown grasses
more than the tufty vegetation
of the South

I would here request
the particular attention of
the reader to the phenomenona
these periodically deluged plains
present because they have
a most important bearing
on the physical geography
27 of a very large portion of
this country - The Plains
of Lobale to the wWest of this
give rise to a great
many streams which Uunite
and form the deep never
failing Chobe - Similar
extensive flats give birth
to the Loeti and Kasai and
as we shall see further on
all the rivers of this an
extensive region owe their
origin to oozing bogs &
not to fountains

When released from our
island by the rain ceasing
we marched on to the till
we came to a ridge of dry
inhabited land in the
N- W-North West The inhabitants
according to custom plent
meus the roofs of some
huts to save the men
the trouble of booth making
I suspect that the story
in Park of the men
lifting up the hut to place
it on the lion referred
to the roof only - It is We leave
28 them for the villagers to
replace them at their leizureleisure
No payment is [expected - By
236 night it rained so copiously
that all our beds were
flooded from below
and from this time forth
we always made a furrow
round each booth and
used the earth to raise our
sleeping places - My men
turned out to work in
the wet most willingly
Indeed they always d did
I would not but contrast
their conduct with that
of Ntemese - He was thoroughly
362
embued with the slave spirit
and lied on all occasions
without compunction - Un-
truthfulness is a sort of refuge
for the weak & oppressed
We expected to move on
on the 4th but he declared
that we were so near Katema's
if we did not send forward
to apprise that chief of our
approach he would certainly
impose a fine - It rained
the whole day so we were
reconciled to the delay but
on Sunday the 5th he let us
know that we were still
two days distant from
Katema - We unfortunately
29 could not manage without
him for the country was
so deluged we should have
been brought to a stand
before we could went many
miles by some deep
valley every one of which
was full of water - Ntemese
continued to plait his basket
with all his might &
would not come to our
service - He seemed to be
afraid of our incantations
but was always merry
merry and jocular

363
Berry 6th Soon after starting we crossed
Lokalueje a branch of the LokaluejeLokalueje
or LokaloozuejeLokalueje by means of a
canoe - and in the afternoon
crossed ˅ passed over the main stream
by a like conveyance - The
former as in the case
of all branches of rivers
in this country is called
Nguana Kalu^sjeKaluje child of the
30 Kaluje - Hippopotami
exist in the LokuejeLokalueje so
it may be inferred to be
perennial ^ as the inhabitants asserted
We cannot judge of the size
of the streams from what
we now see - It was had about
forty yards of of deep fast flowing water
but probably not more
than the half when the that
amount in ^ ^ the season is dry
amount in the dry season -
Besides these we crossed
numerous feeders in our
N- N- W-North North West course and there
being no canoes got frequently
wet in the course of the
day - The oxen have only
in some cases their heads only above water
and the water flowing
over their backs wet our
blankets which we use
as saddles - The arm pit
was the only safe spot for
364
the watch fromfor there it was
preserved from rains above
and waters below - The
men on foot crossed
these gullies by holding
up their burdens at arms
length -

The LokaluejeLokalueje winds from
South East to South West
into the Leeba - The country
adjacent to near its banks is extremely
fine and fertile with here
and there
patches of
forest - or
clumps of
magnificent
trees - The villagers
through whose gardens we
passed continue to sow
and reap all the year
round - The grains - as
Maize - Lotsa millet are
to be seen at all stages of
their growth - some just
reaped while at this time
the Barotse Makololo grains
31 are not half grown My
companions who have
a good idea of the different
qualities ^ kinds of soils express the
greatest admiration of the
agriculture capabilities
of the whole of Londa
and here they were loud
in their praises of the
pasturage - They have an
accurate idea of the
varieties kinds of grasses best
adapted for different kinds
of stock and lament
365
because here there are no
cows to feed off the rich
green crop which at this
time imparts special
beauty to the landscape

Great numbers of
the vegetable omnivorous feeding fish
Glanis siluris or Mosala
spread themselves over
the flooded plains and
as the waters retire try
to find their way back
again to the rivers - The
Balonda make earthen
dykes and hedges across
the points outlets of the
retreating waters leaving
only small spaces through
which the chief part of
32 the water flows - In
these open spaces they
plant creels simlilar in
shape to our own
into which the fish can
enter but not return
They secure large quantities
of fish in this way
which when smoke-
dried make a good relish
for their otherwise insipid
food - They use also
a weir for the same
purpose made of mats
made of reeds sewed together
366
with but half an inch between
each - Open spaces are
left for the insertion of
the creels as before -

In still water a fish
trap is employed of the
same shape and plan
as the ^ common round wire mouse
trap which ashas an opening
surrounded with wires
pointeding inwards - This is
made of reeds and willow
supple wands and food
is placed inside to attract
the fish

Besides these means
33 of catching fish they use
a fihook of iron without
a barb - The point is
bent inwards ^ instead so as not to
allow the fish to escape
Nets are not so common
as in the Zouga and
Leeambye but they kill
large quantities of fishes
by means of the bruizedbruised
leaves of a plant shrub
which may be seen
planted beside every
village in the country -

367
Wheeler We came to the village of
Soana mMolopo, a half brother
of Katema, a few miles
beyond the LokaluejeLokalueje, on the
7th and, when we went
to visit him, he was found,
him sitting, with about one
hundred men - He called
on Ntemese to give some
account of us, though
no doubt had been done
in private before. Then
delivered the following sentences
"The journey of the white man
is very proper, but
Shinte has disturbed us
by shewingshowing the Makololo,
who accompany him,
34 the path to us - He ought to
have taken them through
the country without shewingshowing
them the towns - We are
afraid of the Makololo" He
then gave a handsome
present of food, and seemed
perplexed by my sitting
down familiarly and
giving him a few of our
ideas - When we left
Ntemese continued busily
imparting an idea of all
we had given to Shinte &
Masiko, and instilling the
hope that Soana Molopo might
expect as much as they had recievedreceived
368
accordingly when we expected
to move on the morning
of the 8th we got some
hints about the ox Soana-
mMolopo expected to eat,
but ^ We recommended him to
get the breed for himself,
seeing his country was
so well adapted for
rearing ^ them - And Ntemese
refused to move - - He
moreover tried to frighten
us into parting with
an ox, by saying that
Soana-Molopo would
send forward pa message,
that we were a marauding
35 party, but we bundled
up, and went on without
him - We did not absolutely
need him, but he was
useful in preventing
the inhabitant of secluded
villages from betaking
themselves to flight - We
wished to be on good terms
with all, and therefore
put up with our guide's
peccadilloes - His good
word representing us will
had ^ go a considerable ^ influence way
and he iswas always asked
if we hade behaved our-
-selves like men in the
way - The Malokolo are
369
viewed as great savages,
and but Ntemese could not
justly look down upon
with scorn on them, for he has the mark
of a gash on his arm
got in fighting. , and
he would not tell the
cause of battle, but boasted
of his prowess as the
Makololo do till asked about
a scar in his back betokening
anything but bravery

Ntimese was useful
in such cases asin which
like that of Monday, in
which we came upon
a whole village in a
forest enjoying their
36 noonday nap - Our
sudden appearance
in their midst made them
so terrified, that one woman
nearly went into convulsions
from fear - When they
sayw and heard Ntimese
their terror subsided.

As usual we were
caught by rains, after leaving
Soana Molopo's and made
our booths at the house
of a most intelligent and
friendly man belonging
to Katema - He had a fine
370
large garden in cultivation,
and well hedged round.
He had made the hedge
walls ^ of his compound of the
branches of the banian
or ficus indica, which
taking root had grown
to be a live hedge of that
tree - Several trees were
planted ^ in the middle of it, and
in the deep shade the
whole of them gave, stood
the huts of his fine
family - His children
all by one mother,
37 very black, but comely
to view were the finest
negro family I ever saw
We were much pleased
with the frank friendship
and liberality of this man,
and his wife, she asked
me to bring her a cloth
from the white man's
country but when we
returned poor Mozinkwa's
wife was in her grave,
and he as is the custom
had abandoned trees, garden,
and huts to ruin - They
cannot live on a spot
where a favourite wife
died, - probably because
unable to bear
the remembrance
of the happy times
he has spent
there, or afraid
to remain in a
spot where death
once visited the
establishment
this feeling renders
any permanent
village in the country
impossible If they ever visit
the spot it is to pray to her,
or make some offering
371
Mozinkwa's wife had cotton
growing all round her
compound and several
plants used as relishes
to the insipid potage
of the country - She had also
the castor oil plant and
a larger variety of that same
family which too ˅ also yields
a purgative oil -

The oil here however
is used for anointing
the heads and bodies alone
She had in her garden ˅ alsolikewise
the Indian (Bringalls) too - & yams & sweet
potatoes

Ker We learned from
Mozinkwa that Soana Molopo
38 was the elder brother of
Katema but that he was
swanting in wisdom and
Katema by purchasing
cattle and recievingreceiving in
a kind manner all
the fugitives who came
to him had got secured
the birthright to himself
so far as influence in
the country is concerned
Soana's His first address to us
did not savour much
of the African wisdom

372
Friday 10th On leaving MozinkwasMozinkwa's
hospitable mansion we
crossed another stream about
forty yards wide in canoes
While this tedious process
was going on I was informed
that it is called the Mona-
KaloeuejeKalueje or brother of KaloéuejeKalueje
as it flowes into that river
and that both the KalouejeKalueje
and Livoa flow into the
Chifumadze Leeba - Also that the Chifumadze
swollen by the Lotembwa
is a feeder of that river
too below the point where
we lately crossed it - It may
Here we were met by
39 be remarked here that all
these rivers were now
in flood and though that
the water was all perfectly
clear - The vegetation on
the banks is so thickly
planted that the surface of
the earth is not abraded by the
torrents - The grass is
laid and forms a protection
to the banks which are
generally a stiff black
loam - The fact of canoes
being upon them shewsshows that
though not large they do not possess the
character of ^ the Southern rivulets
which dry up during most
of the year and render canoes
unnecessary

373
As we were crossing the river
we were joined by a messenger
from Katema called Shakatwala
This person was one of those
a sort of steward or factotum
to his chief - Every chief has
one attached to his person
and though generally poor
they are invariably men
of great shrewdness and
ability - Shakatwala They
act the part of messengers
on all important occasions
and possess considerable
authority in the chiefschief's house-
-hold - Shakatwala informed
us that Katema had not
40 recievedreceived precise information
about us but if we were
peacefully disposed weas ˅ as he
loved strangers we were
to come to his town - We
proceeded forthwith but
were turned aside by
the strategy of our friend
Ntemese to the village
of Quendende the father in-
-law of Katema - This
fine old man was so
very polite we did not
regret being obliged to spend
Sunday at his village -
He expressed his pleasure
at having a share in
the honour of a visit
374
as well as Katema - Though
it seemed to me that the conferring
that pleasure required something
like a pretty good stock of
impudence in leading twenty-
seven men through the
country without the means
of purchasing food - My men
did a little business for
themselves in the begging line
They generally commenced
every interview with new
villagers inby saying - "I have
come from afar give me
something to eat - " I forbade
this at first believing
that as the Makololo had
41 a bad name the villagers
gave ^ food from fear - But
after some time it was evident
that in many cases food was
maize and manioc were
given from pure generosity
The first time I came to this
conclusion was at the
house of Mozinkwa - Scarcely
anyone ^ of my men re[turned from
it without something in
240 his hand - and as they
protested they had not asked
begged I asked himself
and found that this was
the case - He gave spontaneously -
H In other parts the chiefs
375
attended to my wants and the
common people gave liberally
to my men - I gave some
of my razors and iron spoons
to different headmen but
my men had nothing and
I found they that each tried to that every
one tried to appropriated
different an individuals in
each village as "bMolekaneMolekane" =
a comrades - and the villagers
often assented - so if the reader
remembers the molekane
system of the Mopato - he
may percieveperceive that those
who presented food freely
would expect the Makololo
to treat them in like manner
42 should they ever be
placed in similar circumstances
Their country too is so
fertile they are in no
want of food themselves
However their generosity
was remarkable - only
one woman refused to
give some of my men
food but her husband
called out to her to be
more liberal and she
obeyed scolding all the
while

376
In this part of the country
buffaloes aElandsElands & other
Khoodoos and other antelopes
are to be found but we
did not get any as they
are exceedingly wary
from being much hunted
We had the same woodland
and meadow as before
with here and there pleasant
negro villages and being
all in good health could
enjoy the fine green scenery -

43 Mead QuendendesQuendende's washead was
a good specimen of the greater
crop of wooliness with which the
negroes of Londa are furnished
The front part was ^ parted in the middle & plaited
into two thick rolls ^ which falling down
behind the ears - reached the
shoulders - The rest was collected
into a large knot which stoodlay
on the nape of the neck -
As he was an intelligent man
we had much conversation
together - and as he had just
come from attending the funeral
of one of his people I found
that the great amount of
drum beating which takes
place on these occasions
was with the idea that the
377
Barimo or spirits could be
drummed to sleep - There is a
drum in every village and
we hear it going often
from sunset to sunrise - They
seem to look upon the departed
as vindictive beings and I
suspect are more influenced
by fear than love

We here met with some
people from the town of
Matiamvo (Muata yanvo) who
had been sent to announce
the death of the late chieftain
44 of that name. Matiamvo is the
hereditary title - Muata meaning
lord or chief - The late chief
Matiamvo seems from their
report ^ of these men to have been insane
for he is said to have sometimes
indulged a whim of running
a muck in the town and
beheading whoever he met,
untilluntil he had quite a heap
of ˅ human heads - They ^ Matiamvo explained this
conduct by saying that hehis
people were too many & he
wanted to diminish them
He had absolute power of life
and death - On enquiring
whether human sacrifices
were still made as in
the time of Pereira ^ at CazembesCazembe's we were
378
informed that these had never
been so common as was
represented to Pereira but that
it occasionally happened when
certain charms were needed
by the chief a man was slaughtered
for the sake of some part of
his pbody. - He added that he
hoped the present chief would
not act like his mad predecessor
but kill only those who were
guilty of witchcraft or theft
These men were very much
45 astonished at the liberty enjoyed
by the Mokololo and when
they found that all my people
held cattle we were told that
Matiamvo alone had a herd -
One very intelligent man among
them asked if he should make
a canoe and take it down
the river to the Makololo would
he get a cow for it - This
question which my men
answered in the affirmative
was important as shewingshowing
the knowledge of a water
communication anfrom
the country of Matiamvo to
the Makololo and the river
runs through
a fertile
country
abounding
in large
timber - If they ^ tribes have
An old courtier of the
same chief
intercourse with each other
it exerts a good influence
379
on their chiefs to hear what
other tribes think of their deeds
The Makololo have such a
bad name yet on account
of their perpetual forays that
they arehave not been known
in Londa buexcept as ruthless
destroyers - The People ^ Lond in Matiamvo's country submit ^ to much
wrong ^ from their chiefs and no
voice can be raised in Londa
against cruelty because they are afraid to
flee elsewhere -

The situationposition of the village of Quendende is 11° 41' 17 South
LongLongitude - 22° 16' - This we left
in company with ^ Quendende and the headman
46 and the ambassadors of Matiamvo
on the 13th and after two or three
miles March to the N- W- North West came
to the ford of the Lotembwa
which flows Southwards - ThA
canoe was waiting to ferry
us over but it was very
tedious work for though
the river itself was only
80 eighty yards wide the
whole valley was flooded
and we were obliged to
paddle more than half a
mile to get free of the water
A fire, was having been lit to
warm theold Quendende and
enable him to dry his
tobacco leaves HisThe leaves
are taken from the plant
380
and spread close to the fire
untilluntil they are quite dry &
crisp - They are then put
into a snuff box which with
a little pestle serves the
purpose of a mill to grind
them into powder - It is then
used as snuff - As we sat
by the fire the ambassadors
communicated their
thoughts freely respecting the
customs of their ˅ race tribe - When a
chief dies a number of
servants are slaughtered with
him to form his company
in the other world - The
47 Barotse followed the same
custom and this and
other customs shewshow them
to be genuine negroes though
neither they nor the Balonda
follow closely the typical
form of that people - Quendende
said wereif he were present
on these occasions he
would hide his people
so that they might not be
slaughtered - As we go North
the people become more
blododily ^ superstitious & more though

If Matiamvo the late
Matiamvo takestook a fancy
to any thing such as my
silver watch chain which was
silver wire plaited - and
381
was a great curiosity as they
had never seem metal plaited
before - he would order a
whole village to be brought
up to buy it from a stranger
and ifthe When a slave trader
visited him he took possession
of all his goods then after
ten days or a fortnight he
would send out a party
of men to pounce upon
some considerable village
and having killed the
headman would pay
48 for all the goods with
the other inhabitants - This
has been athe case frequently
and but nearly all the visitants
he ^ ever had were men of colour
On asking if Matiamvo did
not know he was a man
and would be judged in
company with those he
destroyed by a Lord who
is no respectoer or of persons
The Ambassador replied "We
do not go up to God as you
do, we are put into the
ground" I could not ascer-
tain that even those who
have such a distinct perception
of the continued existence of
departed spirits had any notion
of heaven - They appear to
imagine the souls to be always near the
place of sepulture
